# Draft:Influence of rock and roll in American culture

]]
Infulance of rock and roll in American culture
Rock and roll had influenced many aspects of American culture since its introduction in the mid to late 1950s. Elvis Prestley, who's considered the originator of American rock and roll, "invented" the genre with his hit songs such as: "Blue Sude Shoes" "Jailhouse Rock", etc.    Furthermore, The Beatles came to invade the country, and having massive hits such as: "She Loves You", "I Want To Hold Your Hand",  "Til There Was You", "I've Just Seen a Face", etc.
Tommy Steele is also and orignanator of American rock and roll;  another induvisul from the country's British invasion secne, songs such as "Rock With The Caveman", "Doomsday Rock", " "Come On Let's Go" and "Nirobi", became big in the country further expanding the British invasion in the country. Byu 1964, the Beatles had massive succsesce with not only songs but thier first film; A Hard Day's Night.
Bill Haley & His Comets had massive sussece with "Rock around the Clock".
History
See also: Origins of rock and roll
Location in NYC]]
Elvis Prestley, who's mainly considered the prodeceror of American Rock and Roll, became one of America's most famous musicians of all time. Prestley was also considered one of America's most famous teen heartthrob musicans.  He created one of the most famous singles in history, he sold one billion records, he was in films, and more. The  Missippi-born musician received fame for songs such as "Can't Help Falling in Love With You", "Jailhouse Rock", etc.   Prestley fame had received a cultural impact for himself. Elvis made between 10 and 1 million dollars, thanks to merchandising. Plus, his acting in Love me tender, his first film made him 11 million dollars. Elvis  played in pubs, and bars throughout the country.
Had he not decided to produce more money while making films, he won't haven't made the film popular in the country. During the filming and production of "Can't help Falling in Love With You", and the massive successes of the music all together,  RCA almost rejected him, but the following month when the film was made, he made headlines as one of America's most musicians of the century.
1957-1960: Tommy Steele and Beatles-era
Steele populated america's way of making music in 1958; British-born American musician born on Bramanzy, UK. He made history with his guitar and standing. Another teen heartthrob. Steele preformed many venues throughout the country. Sometime, with this, The New Yorkers announced that in 1959, he would be not working with himself and with other people.
Steele worked in many genres throughout this era, including the Beatles, even noting that John was "MOST INFLUENTUL EVER".
1960-1964: Beatles era
in 1963]]
The Beatles broke ground in America starting in 1964. With their songs and their personalities, they broke records in the country, songs such as "She Loves You", "I Want To Hold Your Hand" and "Twist and Shout" became American Number 1 singles in Billboard.
, USA]]
1965: Help! and more releases from the Beatles and Help! film
Help! came out on August 25th, 1965, and it was an immense success for the band! Richard Lesster, the director for the film, made nearly 205 pounds (253 dollars and 20 cents). Lester was a bit weary about this though, worrying that the film would ruin his career as an film director. John Lennon did not want to bathe next to his own; he went on to say, "Oh, I don't want to bathe in a film".   In Help! They came up with the song "You've Got To Hide Your Love Away".  With Ringo Starr playing the tambarine. Harrison's riff on "I've Just Seen a Face" was quite faced-passed, however, John accepted it anyway.
(1965)]]
1966 to 1970: Rubber Soul, Abby Road, and Let It Be/ the near end of  The Beatles and solo careers+ More releases of songs in America
Main articles: Rubber Soul and breakup of the Beatles
See also: Yoko Ono
]]
, 2011]]
In 1965, John and Paul released songs on what was going to be later Rubber Soul. The songs included on this album have included: "Drive My Car", "Michelle", "Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)", etc. Very much like The Beatles' eliare works "Rubber Soul" included songs written by John Lennon and Paul McCartney. The album was released nearly at the end of the Beatles touring in America, following the release of the album's production, their long-time manager, Brian Epstein, had died on August 25th, 1965 due to drug overdose.
In 1969, John Lennon met Yoko Ono, however the problem was, the rest of the band mates did not like her. Fans have speculated that during the Beatles' 1969-1970 period that Ono was the one to break up the Beatles.
1971 to 1980: Solo careers and the death of John Lennon
See also: The Break up of the Beatles, Assassination of John Lennon, and  The Dakota
On April 10, 1970, the Beatles broke up. about a year after, Lennon released his top selling single; "Imagine".  Over the years, there has been some debate as to which it was either Yoko Ono or Brian who broke up the band. Paul spoke about the Beatles break up relating to Yoko and the solo careers of each members stating: "We.....We were just done with John in general. We won't see him ever". And George spoke out: "We were big! But alias, all good things must come to an end".
On the 9th of December 1980, John was murdered in his Dakota home by Mark David Chapman.  Before that, he released "Stand By Me", which was a cover of the original Ben E. King version.   Lennon was shot while doing his bed ins for peace with his wife, Yoko Ono. Lennon's green card had since been with Ono in remembrance of her husband. The NYPD had recovered a dead carcass of John in his Dakota home where he was shot. this was the last amendance of "The John Lennon Years". The NYPD responded quickly with the accentent; this would be the last year with him.  John thought that Chapman was joking but he shot him right in front of Ono.
